discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. No other answer makes sense or it would cause an outage which goes against every other single feature in a VMware product.

Selected Answer: B
It's B, here's why:

A. vCenter Server performs an in-place upgrade of the Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs.

No - it adds new VMs and deletes the old ones

B. vCenter Server orchestrates the rolling upgrade of Supervisory control plane VMs and upgrades the ESXi host spherelet component.

Yes, add new VMs and delete old ones, rolling

C. An administrator manually deploys new Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs and uses 

No, it's not manual

vSphere Lifecycle Manager to update the ESXi host spherelet component.
D. An administrator downloads and installs new RPMs to the Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs.

No, it's not manual
B vCenter Server orchestrates the rolling upgrade of Supervisory control plane VMs and upgrades the ESXi host spherelet component.

questions.question_text: Which statement accurately describes the upgrade of a vSphere with Tanzu Supervisor Cluster?

choices.C: An administrator manually deploys new Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs and uses vSphere Lifecycle Manager to update the ESXi host spherelet component.
choices.B: vCenter Server orchestrates the rolling upgrade of Supervisory control plane VMs and upgrades the ESXi host spherelet component.
choices.A: vCenter Server performs an in-place upgrade of the Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs.
choices.D: An administrator downloads and installs new RPMs to the Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs.

choices.B: Configure network settings of the image
choices.C: Maintain desired state configuration for containers
choices.D: Secure artifacts with policies and role-based access control

questions.question_text: Which description reflects a use case for an embedded image registry?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It's D, here's why

A. Manage source code changes - No - "Image" registry, not source code registry
B. Configure network settings of the image - No - this is done by Tanzu as the images are deployed, internal or external
C. Maintain desired state configuration for containers - No, this is done through declarative policy
D. Secure artifacts with policies and role-based access control - Yes, because if you have a public image repository, you can't stop people using any part of it they want, so get a private one

questions.question_text:
A company needs its administrators to be able to manage access, apply security policies, and inspect Kubernetes clusters for security and configuration risks across multiple platforms.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Mission Control provides this function.

Selected Answer: D
It should be "D", to satisfy security inspections, apply security policies across multiple platforms. 

TKG is a close answer but this just enables your multiple platform capabilities. Mission Control is the enforcement/management/orchestration thing.
